indicators.justification:
An assessment of the Environmental Protection Agency's website shows that emission data are not available online as a result of government action. Further investigations led to a visit to the EPA and calls to staffers of the agency. These confirmed that emission data were not posted on the agency's website but also revealed that such data are available.

Liberia, has, in 2020 and 2021 made biennial reports to the UNFCCC. these reports have contained information on the country's emissions targets.

https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/BUR1.pdf
https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/SNC.pdf

evidence.title: Liberia’s Second National Communication to the  United Nations Framework Convention on Climate  Change
Liberia’s First Biennial Update Report to UNFCCC

indicators.justification:
Liberia is a part of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN). The country's membership requires it to submit regular data to the organization on its fauna and flora. While this data is retained at the Forestry Development Authority, it is not published as open data online.

Source: Interview with an official of the Forestry Development Authorithy's conservation office.

indicators.justification:
1. Liberia's registration of companies is carried out in two separate ways. One is done domestically by the Liberia Business Registry and the other is done by the Liberian Corporate Registry which serves exclusively registers Liberian non-resident corporate entities.

2. Under Liberia's Association Law, companies are required to file reports of the names and addresses of their registered shareholders. The law gives other shareholders the right to inspect this information. It does not require the companies to make this information available outside their offices.

Companies registered under the Liberian Corporate Registry are not even subject to Liberia laws. On the Liberia Corporate Registry's website it clearly states that corporations registered by them have "No annual reporting or audits" obligations. This declaration on the Registry's website seems to run contrary to the regulation issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 2019. The Regulation seems to impose the same reporting requirements that applies to domestic companies to those registered under the Registry.

For the extractive industry, discussions were started to made beneficial owners known, but those discussions have not led anywhere.

1. https://liberiancorporations.com/about-the-registry/basic-registry-facts/

2. https://liberiancorporations.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/REGULATION-TO-FURTHER-AMEND-THE-ASSOCIATIONS-LAW-OF-LIBERIA-final-version-07112019_Regulation-final.pdf#:~:text=That%20the%20term%2C%20%E2%80%9Cbeneficial%20owner%E2%80%9D%20as%20defined%20in,Liberia%20or%20authorized%20to%20do%20business%20in%20Liberia.

indicators.justification:
While the Association law requires the capture of data for companies by both registries, there is no evidence that such data are made available as open data. They are not even allowed to be inspected by members of the public as Liberia has been a long-standing haven for the registration of companies whose owners can be shielded from public scrutiny.

The Liberia Corporate Registry website states the "No annual reporting or audits" among the basic facts about the Registry as an incentive for foreign companies to be registered in Liberia.

https://liberiancorporations.com/about-the-registry/basic-registry-facts/

indicators.justification:
1, UNICEF notes the importance of a "well-developed and functioning civil registration system" in any country. The organization states that registration of births, deaths, marriages, etc "promotes efficient government planning, effective use of resources and aid, and more accurate monitoring of progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals."

2. The Ministry of Health of Liberia, for its part, notes that a child that is not registered risks being shut out of society and denied the right to an official identity.

Both UNICEF and the Ministry of Health have summed up the importance of vital statistics. While such statistics are required to be collected for births, deaths, and marriages, the data collected is not provided online. There are also no clear policies to view such data.

An official of the Ministry of Health informed the researcher that Liberia is not currently used ICD standards to compile death records.


1. https://data.unicef.org/crvs/liberia/
2. http://moh.gov.lr/civil-registration/

indicators.justification:
An official of the Ministry of Health's vital statists division told the researcher that the government is not currently collecting data on health facilities, though he indicated that they are in the process of rolling out such information.

2) This seems to be confirmed by data available on the WHO's website on Liberia on the availability of medical equipment in the country.

3) The Liberia Institute of Statistics and Geo-Information Services, though has a compilation of data related to the location of hospitals and health facilities across the country. This data, says nothing about the capacities of such facilities.

1) Interview with Ministry of Health official
2) https://www.lisgis.net/pg_img/Health%20Facilities%20by%20County%20and%20District.pdfhttps://www.who.int/medical_devices/countries/lbr.pdf

indicators.justification:
Covid-19 vaccines are currently primarily being rollout only in the country's capital city, Monrovia. As part of the Covax arrangement, Liberia has received two consignments of the Covid-19 vaccine. the first batch was to the tune of about 100,000 doses of Astra Zeneca which ran out in early July. The second batch contained over 300,000 doses of the Johnson and Johnson shots. Presently, from government sources, it is difficult to tell how many people have been vaccinated against Covid-19 in Liberia.

https://www.afro.who.int/news/liberia-launches-johnson-and-johnson-jj-covid-19-vaccine-boosts-vaccination-campaign

indicators.justification:
The government provides very little information about land use in the country. The available data is mainly put together by private initiatives or work done by US government agencies. The data is not recent and represents areas designated as degraded forest, agricultural land, savanna, etc.

The data, however, does not represent the land area used for building settlements.

https://eros.usgs.gov/westafrica/land-cover/land-use-land-cover-and-trends-liberia

indicators.justification:
Liberia's Land Rights Act was passed into law in 2018. The Act redefined land ownership and created categories of Land. These are Private Land, Government Land, Public Land and Customary Law. Prior to the passage of the Act, there were essentially only two categories. Any land that was not deeded was regarded as being owned by the government.

Before the Act was passed, land tenure in Liberia was basically administered by the Ministry of Lands, Mines, and Energy and to some extent the Center for National Documentation and Records where all land deeds were required to be requested.

The researcher spoke with the Public Information Officer of the Liberia Land Authority. He stated that the LLA's website was offline because of a cyber attack. He also noted that the website, when it was online, did not contain data pertaining to land ownership although all relevant legislation pertaining to land will be contained on it.

Source: Interview with the Public Information Officer of the Liberia Land Authority.

indicators.justification:
Liberia's budgets are published publicly every year. Going back to 2014/2015 all of the country's budgets are available on the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning's website.

The Public Financial Management Act governs all matters related to the management of public finances in Liberia. The Act prescribes procedures for the budgeting process. The law, though, does not clearly provide guidelines on how data arising out of the country's financial management can be published.

https://mfdp.gov.lr/index.php/main-menu-reports/mm-bdp/mm-bd-nb

indicators.justification:
None of this information is available online as the law requiring the submission of asset declaration expressly prohibits their publication unless through a court order. Assets declared to the National Elections Commission for the purpose of participating in elections though are not governed by such restrictions, but the Commission has since 2005 failed to publish such declarations as open data.

https://www.rfi.fr/en/africa/20210123-liberia-george-weah-s-property-empire-fuels-distrust-over-asset-declaration-corruption-allegations

https://zammagazine.com/investigations/1418-the-happy-few-s-happy-places-how-liberian-politicians-and-officials-escape-accounting-for-their-wealth

https://allafrica.com/stories/202106040548.html

Code of Conduct for All Public Officials, Section 10.1. 2014. https://www.emansion.gov.lr/doc/Act_Legislature_Prescribing_A_National_Code%20of_Conduct%20(Final_Version%202014).pdf

indicators.justification:
There is no information required to be collected on lobbying in Liberia. Though Section 9.1 (Bribes and Gifts) of the Code of Conduct of 2014 requires the passage of legislation to regulate lobbying, no such action has been taken by the government.

Code of Conduct for All Public Officials, Section 9.1. 2014. https://www.emansion.gov.lr/doc/Act_Legislature_Prescribing_A_National_Code%20of_Conduct%20(Final_Version%202014).pdf

indicators.justification:
While political finance information is required to be submitted to the National Elections Commission every year, it is difficult to know whether political parties and independent candidates actually abide by the law or whether the NEC enforces it as stringently.

In May 2016, the NEC issued its Campaign Finance Regulation which requires all political parties and independent candidates to make filings annually. The Regulation also requires that candidates and political parties will make declarations 15 days following the announcement of the result of each election they participated in.

Campaign Finance Regulations, 2016. https://www.necliberia.org/pg_img/4%20Campaign%20Finance%20Regulations.pdf

indicators.justification:
Liberia Freedom of Information Act requires each government agency to retain data on their responses to freedom of information requests. They are also required to retain the information even in situations where the request for information is denied. All such reports are required to be made to the Office of Information Commissioner. The reality though is that this is hardly ever done.

https://www.cima.ned.org/blog/access-to-information-in-liberia/

indicators.justification:
1) While Liberia has obligated itself to hold public consultation as part of its OGP requirements, this is rarely ever done. Individual government agencies like the Liberia Telecommunication Authority, National Oil Company, Forestry Development Authority, etc have carried out such consultations in the past. Of these, the LTA has published some of its consultation information on its website.

The lower confidence is based on the lack of clear information on consultations. The lack of a binding statutory requirement for the collection of such data has also contributed to the low confidence.

1) https://www.lta.gov.lr/publications/

indicators.justification:
A British government scoping study on open contracting concluded, "disclosure of procurement data	is not standard practice" in Liberia. The study concluded that the information that has been disclosed is "fragmented through different information channels" and exists in formats that are not user-friendly to enable easy analysis. The report described published data as untimely.

https://developmentgateway.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Open-Contracting-West-Africa-Liberia-Development-Gateway.pdf

evidence.title: Open Contracting Scoping Study: Liberia Country Report

indicators.justification:
The researcher found no evidence of the Liberian government encouraging data reuse of any kind. NO information was found concerning government efforts to support data reuse in any form.

While there have been hackathons carried out by civil society organizations in the country, most of these have focused on other issues like media uses of technology and climate actions to foster the SDGs.

https://www.ilabliberia.org/hackathons

Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

indicators.justification:
Liberia's ascension to the Open Government Partnership has not generally translated into the country establishing structures that will ensure the publication of open data across the government. The open data in Liberia is largely focused on the publication of the country's budget, procurement information and concessions related to the extractive sector.

Speaking with the researcher, the government minister responsible for OGP coordination, noted that the process is still sector focus with each government agency driving their individual open data agenda.

This lack of a clear commitment to publishing can be seen from the threadbare nature of the country's Data Portal: https://liberia.opendataforafrica.org/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of an active government-led open government data initiative.

There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiatives covers much of both national and sub-national government.

indicators.justification: The researcher did not find any capacity among local government actors on their ability to manage data. Only one local government office, the City of Monrovia, has a website in Liberia. The City of Monrovia's website (https://www.monrovia.gov.lr/) is largely devoid of data of any kind.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.

There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: No cities or regions show capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
The only institution responsible for providing short term training for in-service government workers is the Liberia Institute of Public Administration (LIPA). The institute currently provides a single 4-week course in records and library management. LIPA currently has no course on data literacy and data skills. The deputy director-general of LIPA told the researcher in an interview that there were plans to introduce data literacy in their curriculum.

https://lipa.com.lr/course_details.html

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of government supporting civil servants training on data matters.

Training on data addresses non-technical public servants.
Training on data is focused on specific positions already working with data.
Training is planned by an established training team, department, or agency.
Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

indicators.justification:
There is no publication of such data as open data. Though the National Elections Commission largely requires political parties and candidates to submit financial records regularly. Similar data on officeholders and other politically significant individuals are held under wraps. This makes it difficult to cross-reference them across various data sources.

https://allafrica.com/stories/202106040548.html

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.

Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
1. Liberia carried out a pilot program on beneficiary ownership disclosure in the extractive sector prior to 2016. Under the scheme, a 5% disclosure target was set for companies in the agriculture sector while 10% was set for those in the oil sector.

2. In 2019 the government issued a regulation requiring companies to retain information on beneficial owners of shares.

Neither of the schemes though did create an open data requirement for the disclosure of such information.

1. https://eiti.org/files/documents/leiti_bo_roadmap.pdf
2. https://liberiancorporations.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/REGULATION-TO-FURTHER-AMEND-THE-ASSOCIATIONS-LAW-OF-LIBERIA-final-version-07112019_Regulation-final.pdf

evidence.title: REGULATION IN FURTHERANCE OF THE ASSOCIATIONS LAW OF LIBERIA

indicators.justification:
There is no such arrangement backed by any laws. There have been some movements on the electoral front to provide special ballots to blind or visually impaired people during elections. In spite of this prevailing situation concerning disabled people in Liberia, the government in a report to the UN on disability stated its commitment to ensuring a more inclusive society for people living with disabilities.

https://pmun.gov.lr/index.php/news-and-events/142-government-of-liberia-committed-to-ensuring-inclusive-society-develops-policies-and-programs-for-people-with-disabilities

Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.

indicators.justification:
Currently, there is no comprehensive data management policy administered by the Liberian government. Being a part of the Open Government Partnership and Open Budget Initiative, the government elects to publish its annual budget, procurement information and expenditure. The country also publishes data related to the extractive sector as part of its Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.

The Deputy Minister of Information responsible for the coordination of the Open Government Partnership told the researcher that the government does not have any plans yet to put in place data management policy.

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

indicators.justification:
1) There is not a single framework or guidance that governs the collection and publication of data in Liberia. The system has worked such that different initiatives are governed by separate guidelines. for example, the Center for National Documentation, Records and Archives (CNDRA) is required to carry out periodic checks to enable it to take possession of important papers from across the government. Information captured by the CNDRA is not required to be published as open data.

2) The Liberia Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (LEITI) focuses on publishing information related to the extractive sector. Information captured under the LEITI process is required to be published as open data.

1) Executive Law, Subchapter B, Section 20.52 (a). 1972. http://www.liberlii.org/cgi-bin/disp.pl/lr/legis/codes/elt12lcolr429/elt12lcolr429.html?stem=0&synonyms=0&query=executive%20law

2) Extractive Industries and Transparency Initiative (LEITI) Act Section 4.1 (f). 2009, http://www.liberlii.org/cgi-bin/disp.pl/lr/legis/acts/eiatia582/eiatia582.html?stem=0&synonyms=0&query=liberia%20extractive%20industry%20transparency%20initiative

evidence.title: Extractive Industries and Transparency Initiative (LEITI) Act

How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
1) The government passed the National Identification Registry Act in 2011. The purpose of the Act is to provide for a biometric identification system for the country. The law also gave the institution established to administer it the authority to make rules for data protection. As yet, no such rules have been generally promulgated. The director of the Registry made this clear to the researcher in a telephone conversation. He also confirmed that the Registry has no functional website and that its searchable database is only available to a few institutions that use it for verification purposes.

2) Liberia passed its freedom of information law in 2010. The law has very limited provisions on individual data protection.

3) The Ministry of Post and Telecommunication has led efforts to introduce a Cybercrime Act. Those efforts have gone on since 2017 with the last review happening in 2019. The draft Cybercrimes Act is thin on the protection of personal data even though it contains some provisions that could be construed as protective of privacy. The Draft Cybercrimes Bill is currently available in hardcopy only.

1) National Identification Registry Act. 2011. (no URL available)
2) Freedom of Information Act. 2010. http://www.liberianembassyus.org/uploads/documents/Liberia%20Freedom%20of%20Information%20Act%202010x.pdf
3) Cybercrimes Bill. 2018. (no URL available)

indicators.justification:
The Constitution of Liberia mandates that all government documents are done in English until such time that the country can make preparations that will allow the usage of one or more of the local languages spoken in Liberia. At present, none of the country's indigenous languages is used in any official capacity except in instances where there is a need to provide verbal interpretation during meetings or providing explanations to people who cannot speak English.

Constitution of Liberia, Article 41. 1986. http://www.liberlii.org/lr/legis/const/col1986235/

indicators.justification:
There is currently no law or policy across the government that guides the generation and publication of open data. This is the situation even though Liberia has been a member of the open government partnership for many years now. An exception to this situation is the Liberia Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (LEITI). The LEITI publishes open data on all concessions that operate in the extractive sector.

http://www.leiti.org.lr/about-leiti.html

indicators.justification:
Liberia's Public Finance Management Act requires the collection of information related to public debts and ensures that reports related to such debts are given to the president and legislation twice a year. The Act also requires that the national budget is made available to the public in draft form and after it is passed into law by the legislature.

The budget is published every year in keeping with the Public Finance Law. While the budget includes the expenditure or performance report for the previous year, the performance report does not report data for individual expenditures.

https://www.moci.gov.lr/doc/Public%20Finance%20Management%20Act.pdf

indicators.justification:
The law is clear about the declaration of assets by every public official in all three branches of the Liberian government. Since the Code of Conduct was passed in 2014, public officials have argued against the publication of their declared assets on grounds that it will endanger their safety. Even President Ellen Sirleaf made the same argument but she later published her assets in the last few months of her presidency. Her successor has made a similar argument and refused to allow his asset declaration to be published. There have been numerous media reports concerning the failure of government officials to file asset declarations.

https://www.rfi.fr/en/africa/20210123-liberia-george-weah-s-property-empire-fuels-distrust-over-asset-declaration-corruption-allegations

indicators.justification:
While Section 9.1 of the Code of Conduct requires the Legislature to enact laws for the regulation of lobbying in Liberia, no such laws have been enacted in the country. Lobbying is something that many Liberian government officials do not distinguish from bribery. Most of them always try to blur the lines between the two which is the reason why no law regulating lobbying has been passed in the country since the Code of Conduct mandated such an action in 2014.

Code of Conduct for All Public Officials, Section 9.1. 2014. https://www.emansion.gov.lr/doc/Act_Legislature_Prescribing_A_National_Code%20of_Conduct%20(Final_Version%202014).pdf

evidence.title: A NATIONAL CODE OF CONDUCT FOR ALL PUBLIC OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES OF THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF LIBERIA

indicators.justification:
The laws related to the collection and publication of campaign finances are clear, but for many years now, such information has not been made publicly available. Candidate asset declarations have partially been disclosed as a result of a recent Freedom of Information request by a journalist.

It has been difficult for the asset declaration provisions of the various laws to work since there is no compulsion to publish especially under the Code of Conduct Act which requires the release of declarations only through a court order. Court processes especially for civil cases take an extremely long time in Liberia.

https://zammagazine.com/investigations/1418-the-happy-few-s-happy-places-how-liberian-politicians-and-officials-escape-accounting-for-their-wealth

indicators.justification:
1) While the country is a member of the Open Government Partnership that requires the holding of consultations to make the legislative processes more transparent and participatory. Despite this obligation, there has been no broad issuance of specific guidance on how government agencies can collect and publish data.

2) This is the situation except in the case of the National Budget which the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning is required to publish in draft form for public consumption before it is passed into law. The Ministry is also required to publicly publish it after it is passed into law.

The low confidence regarding the data here is based on the lack of a strong legal requirement related to mandating the holding of public consultations.

indicators.justification:
Liberia's Freedom of Information law requires that each government agency will collect data related to its implementation of the Act and submit this data to the Information Commissioner on an annual basis. This requirement has hardly been met as the Independent Information Commission which is also required to make annual reports to the legislature hard ever does so.

https://www.cima.ned.org/blog/access-to-information-in-liberia/

indicators.justification:
In the general scheme of business relationships, people should know who they intend to get into a business relationship with. So due diligence has to be done by either or both parties. The onus is on the individuals or companies. There is no government tool to help in this regard in Liberia.

In Liberia, there are no tools available for a business to countercheck another business as a means of verifying information about them. Neither the government nor private actors provide such service.

There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.

There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data

indicators.justification:
There have been numerous reports of land tenure issues leading to conflicts between big companies and people who reside in their concession areas. Such clashes have led to changes in policy that have provided slightly more rights to people living in the countryside who have historically had no legal rights to the land on which they reside.

The Reuters news agency reported on one such conflict in its story "Land rights at the root of palm oil conflict in Liberia, campaigners say".

The confidence level for this indicator is low because there is little evidence that advocacies have had any direct impact on shifts in land use policies in Liberia.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-liberia-land-palmoil-idUSKCN0XX17U
indicators.indicator_name: Use (L): Influencing policy for gender and inclusion
indicators.indicator_name_medium: Gender and inclusion uses of data
indicators.indicator_name_short: Gender and inclusion uses of data

responses.response_text: There are a number of cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification: There is little evidence that data available for political integrity have been used vigorously to highlight or expose failings in government. There has been the occasional publication of news stories on governance shortcomings related to asset declarations and campaign financing. Such stories are also usually linked to occasional civil society advocacies on the same issues. There is practically no evidence that such data is even used by academics in any way.

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
A report supported by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office of the United Kingdom recommended that Liberia's Public Procurement and Concession Act be amended to include a mandatory provision for data to be published on all stages of the procurement process in user friend formats. The report concluded that the current voluntary system of data disclosure was inadequate and did not afford civil society the opportunity to systematically analyze data for anti-corruption monitoring purposes.

https://developmentgateway.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Open-Contracting-West-Africa-Liberia-Development-Gateway.pdf

evidence.title: Open Contracting Scoping Study: Liberia Country	Report

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of this use.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
